title: Georgia House - Day 7 (2026-01-23)
summary:
Overview: The Georgia House session featured a powerful prayer from Rabbi Adam Starr, the senior rabbi of Congregation B'nai Torah in Sandy Springs. The prayer drew inspiration from the biblical story of Jethro providing guidance to Moses, emphasizing the importance of legislators being "people of valor, God-fearing, people of truth, haters of ill-gotten gain." No substantive legislative actions were detected in the transcript.

Key Actions: None detected.

Bills Introduced (First Reading): None detected.

Notable Moments:
- Rabbi Adam Starr delivered an inspiring prayer, calling on legislators to have the courage, moral compass, and integrity to serve the greater good.
- The House recognized Dr. James Short as the doctor of the day, invited by Representative Mary Margaret Oliver.
- Committee Chair Rep. Tarvan reported the journal from the previous legislative day was found to be correct.

Votes: None detected.

Attendance: Quorum was present.

Adjournment: The transcript does not provide the exact time of adjournment or the date of the next scheduled session.
transcript:
you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you I saw us with an amazing love and love, love fly with us you as the senior rabbi of congregation Benetara of Sandy Springs since 2004. He is a ninth generation rabbi. During his time in Georgia, he has grown the synagogue to become one of the largest Jewish congregations in the entire state. We have 900 families in membership. He has served many leadership roles in our community, including his president of the Atlanta Rebinnical Association, board member of the Jewish Federation of Greater Atlanta, and Jewish Family and Career Services. Rabi Heller has served on the Sandy Springs City Ethics Commission and the Commission on Diversity. Rabi Heller is visible on the national scene as a member of the committee on Jewish law and standards, and a member of the advisory board of the Pozen Library of Jewish Culture and Civilization. Before becoming a leader in our community, Rabi Heller graduated from Harvard University with honors and published research in the journal for Computational Neuroscience and served as director of distance learning for the Jewish Theological Seminary. During the period after 9-11, he served as the rabbi of the downtown synagogue, having started his job on September 9. It was one of the synagogue's closest to the site of the World Trade Center. Rabi Heller and his wife Wendy are the proud parents of three children. Welcome, Rabi Heller. Thank you. Mr. Speaker, honored representatives, thank you for allowing me to bring you blessings today. As we reflect on the awesome work that each of you has committed to carry out, let us take the words of Exodus chapter 18 for inspiration and guidance. It is the story of a man named Jethro, not the clampets denwitted cousin, but Moses's thoughtful father-in-law. He was the high priest of Midian, and he heard about all the troubles that the Israelites had encountered and how God saved them, liberating them from slavery in Egypt, bringing them through the waters of the sea, saving them from implacable foes who attacked, and bringing them on their way to the promised land. On my heart this morning is the journey, the wilderness through which my people wander at this very moment. That is a burden that I bring and carry with me, but my task today is to bring blessing to you. So let me share with you the words that Jethro brought to Moses. So Jethro saw Moses judging the people from early in the morning to very late at night every day. It was like signy die every day. And he sees Moses and he says, you can do better, and he suggested to Moses appoint yourself a legislature. Jethro says, seek out from amongst all the people, people of valor, God fearing people, people of truth, haters of ill-gotten gain. And Jethro is saying that only with people of that caliber, leaders of tens of fifties of hundreds of thousands, will this nation come to its rightful place, its promised land in peace. I'd like to suggest that the advice that Jethro gave is the very same advice and guidance that we ourselves need, that we need to see ourselves as being from among the people, knowing that we each represent an important segment of the community, that we have to be people of courage, being willing to act for truth even if it is against what is popular, that we must be people who are God fearing. It is not enough to have convictions, but those convictions can't be the convictions that lead to convictions. We have to have a moral compass. We have to be on se, I met, we have to be people of truth, with the wisdom and discernment, to understand the reality of a matter, even when others might seek to obscure it. We must be haters of ill-gotten gain, we must come with integrity and look for the good of all, not just for the good of ourselves. Now of course the greatest miracle of the Bible, I don't know if it's that a father-in-law has useful advice or that a son-in-law chooses to take it, but indeed it is a chapter later that Moses has taken this advice and with that legacy in place, the people of Israel, the children of Israel are able to receive the Ten Commandments, a legacy that we, that they would pass on to the world and are still in North Star for so many. With that verse, with that lesson in mind, let us pray. God of all, we ask your blessings for these men and women who have taken on the awesome responsibility of service to the people of the state of Georgia. Help them be, as Jethro said, from among the people remembering always whom they are here to serve. Help them be people of courage, not afraid to say what must be said even if it is not what brings accolades or approval. Help them to be God-fearing guided by faith and conscience. Help them to be people of truth with the discernment to reach the heart of every matter, even when facts are obscured by rhetoric so that they may enact laws and carry out policies that benefit all who live and work in our state. Help them to be haters of ill-gotten gain. Let them approach every issue with integrity without regard to their own well-being, without temptation. Let them have the strength of character to always put ethics before ego, purpose before personality, and public before party. Let our lawmakers indeed be worthy so that you may bless them. Bless our lawmakers with wisdom to ensure the safety and security, the health and wholeness of all who dwell here. Bless them with the vision to help our state preserve the beautiful gifts of nature that you have given us. Bless them with discernment to alleviate poverty and seek prosperity for all. Bless them with the insight to conduct their affairs with integrity. Bless them as they leave their home and work untended to offer service to the greater good. Watch over their families, their businesses, their homes, bless partners and children, co-workers and clients, and all who wait for their return. And may their sacrifices of time and treasure yield blessings for all. May they be illuminated, Lord, by your light, to be people of the nation, to be people of courage, to be the fears of God, to be people of truth, to be haters of the all-gotten gain, so that the people of Georgia, all of us, your children, to reach the place of your promises, the places of truest potential in peace, and let us all say amen. Now we recite the pledge. I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and I remember in all the for which it stands, one nation under God, with liberty and justice for all. Also, thank you, Mike. Thank you so much. Thank you. Get one? Yes, sir. Thank you, Rabbi Heller, for those words and your lessons and your encouragement. Over the past few weeks, I've sat at my seat back there and listened very intently about maternal mortality from my colleagues. And I've listened to them speak at length about the impact that it's having on women across our state and how it's affecting their families. And on those points, I couldn't agree more. But what has been glaringly and alarmingly absent from every single speech that they've given on this issue, as is typical with many of the issues they raise, are tangible solutions to the problem. And that's because they have none. There is no substance, no concrete plan, no action. It's a complaint filled words. Standing up here and referring to women as birthing people does not save women's lives. And releasing statements tying our maternal mortality rate to a lack of Medicaid expansion when Medicaid has already been expanded for expected mothers and their children is not only disingenuous, but dangerous. Since the beginning of session, they have stood up here and told the people of Georgia that they are urging Republicans to act on this important issue. But the truth is we have. Republicans in the House, under the leadership of Speaker Rauston and Speaker Burns, have worked on solutions and delivered results on this issue going all the way back to 2014 when the Georgia Maternal Mortality Review was created. Since then, Republicans have proactively led on this issue to deliver real results. And I'd like to read you some of those efforts that have been made over the last five years. A study committee was led by Chairwoman Cooper in 2019. It paved the way for significant policy to address the issue. House Bill 1114 and 2020 and later Senate Bill 338 in 2022 extended postpartum Medicaid coverage from mothers up to a year after birth, providing critical, continual care for an additional year. Senate Bill 106, the Healthy Babies Act, passed last year and was signed into law by the Governor that creates a Medicaid program to provide remote maternal health clear services to women with high risk pregnancies and rural areas. House Bill 911, our fiscal year's budget, included 800,000 to increase, select OBGYN reimbursement levels, which will increase access to expecting mothers. And the other in House Bill 19, another budget, it provided $1.7 million to fund the pilot program within Senate Bill 106 to provide home visits and at risk and underserved rural communities and through early childhood. It included $47.9 million in ongoing funding to provide coverage through 12 months post delivery. And it eliminated the waiting period for children and pregnant women to receive Medicaid. And finally Senate Bill 35, which was agreed to yesterday by this body, it required glucose monitors to be covered as a benefit for Medicaid recipients to address diabetes, which is one of the leading complications of infant mortality. These are just a handful of solutions that Republicans in this body have delivered on to address maternal mortality in our state. And as someone who just recently survived a very complicated and high risk pregnancy, I want to offer my sincere gratitude to Chairwoman Cooper for her continued efforts around maternal health because it is possible that I wouldn't be standing here today with you guys if it were not for the efforts that have been made over the last decade. Today I have a number of resolutions so bear with me. I'm going to try and talk fast. But the first is to recognize today as maternal health awareness day. And I have a group of women in the gallery if you guys want to stand. They will be sharing their stories later on. They're here with healthy mothers, healthy babies. And they're going to be sharing their stories in Liberty Plaza from 3 to 5 p.m. this afternoon. And so I would encourage all of my colleagues to stop by if you have the time. Second, I would like to recognize Miss Sharina Heinz Rush if you could stand up. This woman was solely responsible for keeping me in the hospital and recognizing the life-threatening issues that I was experiencing. And so I brought her today and I'd also like to shout out some of my doctors because I owe an immense amount of gratitude to them. Dr. Tameka C. Dr. Topay Fapahunda. My midwife Shannon Mayfield and my team of nurses Susan Katie Tammy Sharina, Aura and LaShika. Please help me recognize their efforts and contributions to maternal and infant care in Georgia. I'll end my statements today by saying I believe that it is vital that we are honest with the women of the state about the efforts that are being made to improve maternal and fetal outcomes so that women will feel comfortable seeking care when they need it most. While I cannot say whether or not my friends across the aisle will continue to stand up here and politicize this important issue, I can guarantee that we in this body will continue to lead and we will seek solutions because that is what the women of Georgia deserve.
